Misconstruction of ακοόγραμμα (akoógramma) audiogram
From false etymology ακού(ω) (“I hear”) + -ο- + γράμμα,
the correct being ακο(ή) (“hearing”) + -ο- + γράμμα (“letter”) > ακοόγραμμα

Misconstruction of ακοομέτρης (akoométris) audiometrist
From false etymology ακού(ω) (“I hear”) + -ο- + μέτρο/-μέτρης (“-metrist”)
the correct being ακο(ή) (“hearing”) + -ο- + μέτρο (“measure, meter”)/-μέτρης > ακοομέτρης

Misconstruction of ακοομετρία (akoometría) audiometry
From false etymology ακού(ω) (“I hear”) + -ο- + μέτρο + -ία,
the correct being ακο(ή) (“hearing”) + -ο- + μέτρο (“measure, meter”) + -ία > ακοομετρία

Misconstruction of ακοόμετρο (akoómetro) audiometer
From false etymology ακού(ω) (“I hear”) + -ο- + μέτρο,
the correct being ακο(ή) (“hearing”) + -ο- + μέτρο (“measure, meter”) > ακοόμετρο

The upper case letter gamma (γάμα), the third letter
The number three in Greek numerals.

Lower-case gamma, the third letter of the modern Greek alphabet. Its name is γάμμα or γάμα and it represents either a voiced velar fricative: /ɣ/ or a voiced palatal fricative: /ʝ/; before velars, it represents a velar nasal: /ŋ/. It is preceded by β and followed by δ.

ending of formal adjectives in -ης, -ης, -ες or -ής, -ής, -ές deriving from the corresponding ancient 3rd declension
e.g. πλήρης (plíris, “full”) < πλήρης, αήθης (aḯthis, “immoral”) < ἀήθης

genitive singular ending of feminine nouns and adjectives ending in -η deriving from ancient genitive -ης or -ῆς
e.g. της φίλης f (fílis, “friend (female)”) < τῆς φίλης
e.g. της μουσικής f (mousikís, “music”) < τῆς μουσικῆς

adverbs in -ής deriving from genitive feminine ending, Hellenistic or Medieval -ῆς.
e.g. επικεφαλής (epikefalís, “in charge”), καταγής (katagís, “down on the ground”)

ending of 2nd person, singular, subjunctive used until the 1960s, deriving from its ancient -ῃς (-ēis) equivalent

occurs before sibilants [s, z] (the [s] plus consonant)

occurs colloquially before [v, γ, δ, f, x, θ, ks, ps]
δ - συν- (“together”) + δέντρο (“tree”) → σύδεντρο (“group of trees”) /ˈsiðendro/

χ - συγχαίρω (“congratulate”) /siŋˈçero/  < συν + χαίρω (chaíro, “rejoice”)
